raw_response: {"answer_index": 2, "answer_text": "Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "This clinical presentation is classic for opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS) associated with neuroblastoma. The key features are: 1) A 2-year-old child (peak age for neuroblastoma), 2) Opsoclonus (chaotic, multidirectional saccadic eye movements), 3) Myoclonus (brief involuntary muscle contractions), 4) Ataxia (unsteady gait), and 5) An abdominal mass. Neuroblastoma is a tumor of neural crest origin that arises from sympathetic ganglia or adrenal medulla. Histologically, it characteristically shows small round blue cells (neuroblasts) arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes around central neuropil (eosinophilic neural processes). The other options represent: 0) Burkitt lymphoma, 1) Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma), and 3) Hepatoblastoma. While Wilms tumor can present as an abdominal mass in this age group, it would not cause OMS, which is a paraneoplastic syndrome specifically associated with neuroblastoma."}
